content: The Bush tax cuts, enacted in 2001 and 2003, were set to expire at the end of 2010. This would have resulted in higher capital gains and dividends tax rates. President Obama proposed to retain lower rates for lower- and middle-income taxpayers but increase rates for higher-income individuals. The tax rates were temporarily extended through 2012 and finally resolved in 2013 with the American Taxpayer Relief Act. The final resolution in 2013 raised capital gains taxes for higher-income individuals, with thresholds set at $480,050 for married couples and $453,350 for singles in 2018. The potential revenue gain from this increase is influenced by behavioral responses assumed by the Joint Committee on Taxation and the Department of the Treasury. The Obama Administration estimated a revenue increase of $16 billion in FY2019 by allowing the Bush tax cuts for capital gains to expire, while the Congressional Budget Office projected an increase from 13.3% to 17.9% in the effective capital gains tax rate from 2008 to 2019, resulting in a revenue difference of $40 billion. Assumptions about behavioral responses are the main factor affecting the reduction in projected revenues. Some supporters propose applying mark-to-market rules to tax capital gains as accrued to address potential behavioral responses and eliminate realization response for affected assets. Look-back treatment could be applied to assets that are less easily valued to achieve the same after-tax earnings. Individual data is preferred due to information loss and potential bias in aggregate data.
